ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Russian history and language
I learned A LOT of information on Russian revolution. I have a very detailed understanding now about what happened in those years as well as the main figures, and I really liked the historical focus.
A much better understanding of the Russian Revolution and the personalities involved in it.

This course really helped me with my Russian literacy, especially understanding the general points of complicated texts in which I struggled with much of the specific vocabulary. It also was fascinating to learn in depth and from primary sources about the progression of the Russian Revolution over the course of 1917.
An in depth knowledge of the Russian revolutions of 1917.
Knowledge of Russian history while developing Russian language skills.

Through this course, I was able to learn about the Russian Revolution in great detail by reading the accounts of the main political actors of that time. I learned a lot about the different political parties of that time, how the government transitioned, how the Bolsheviks were able to take power, and about the biggest issues and struggles facing the country. I was also able to greatly improve my reading and writing skills in Russian through the readings and reading responses.
I improved my Russian language skills, especially reading comprehension, and learned a lot about the Russian Revolution (I knew very little about it before the class)

I got an amazing sense of the characters involved in the Russian Revolution, especially on the side of the the Kadets and SRs. Additionally, my Russian significantly improved, mostly in reading ability, but also in speaking and listening.
I learned a lot of vocabulary and history related to the Russian revolutions from 1905-17.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strength: Immersive and detail oriented/academic conversations and language
Weakness: If it's above your language level, it's incredibly hard to know what is going on

Strength: since class is a seminar, definitely kept me engaged. The assignments and assessments are also constant, which is both a pro and a con. Weakness: the readings can feel overwhelming at times. They are often very dense and can be confusing. Definitely great to read sources like that but maybe assigning less would be helpful.

The biggest strength of this class is the professor. Professor Muravnik is one of the best professors at Yale, he is very kind and attentive to his students. He is always very engaged in the seminar and flexible in terms assignments. As for the material, reading primary documents and comparing different points of view is a great way to learn history.

The biggest weakness was that we focus to much on the readings and spent a lot of time in class just answering the questions, which were directly related to the text. I think it would be better if readings only served as a background and we were able to learn more new material in class and discuss share our own thoughts on the subject instead of reciting the assigned readings.

I found the lectures fascinating, and I think the tests were a good way to engage with the texts and measure our comprehension. I think the breakout rooms to answer questions about the texts were at times a little hectic and overwhelming, but when discussion was a bit more open I enjoyed it more, and the lecture was very helpful as a format to give context to the readings. As a non-native Russian reader, the texts were at times a bit long and difficult for me, and perhaps could have benefited from shorter selections.

The main weakness of this course is that all of the knowledge is taught based around primary readings. They are fantastic and useful, but for such a complicated history it would have been really useful had we started each unit with one lecture class to go through all of the key players and events before delving into the primary readings.

This course is extremely well-organized, interesting, and facilitates student learning greatly. The readings, assignments, and in-class discussions really worked very well together. The course was split up into four units, each covering a few months of the revolution. After each unit, there was a quiz and exam, which really helped with solidifying the knowledge of the material before moving on to the next unit. All of the excerpts that we read added something interesting to my understanding of the Russian Revolution and they complemented each other well because it gave us the opportunity to see and understand different perspectives of the same events. The professor was wonderful and very supportive, always giving us clear feedback on all of our assignments. Although this is not a weakness, I think that the student presentations sometimes were not as helpful as our in-class discussions and breakout room conversations. Although they were interesting and it was great to hear how other students understood the text, I think that sometimes the presentations took up a lot of class time and there was a lot of material to cover so sometimes we did not get to everything. However, overall, the course is really wonderful and I would recommend it.
There is a lot of reading (all in Russian) that is pretty difficult for non-native speakers, but if you set aside time to do them they're manageable

The course was very interesting, engaging, and informative. It was exactly what you would want out of an upper-level language course, that is to say, you forget that you are even in a language course. It could be improved by simply having more class time. I know that's not necessarily possible, but I feel that this course would make an amazing 1.5 or even 2 credit intensive reading course.

This course dives very very deep into the history of this period using primary and secondary evidence. The professor is also incredibly well versed as both a historian and linguist. The materials and resources are very dense and very hard to follow. I felt incredibly overwhelmed by the content and by the structure of the exams.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Asynchronous quizzes and tests were definitely a plus. However, I don't think that breakout rooms are very useful for facilitating discussion in the class.

The two main ways of encouraging active engagement were breakout rooms to answer questions and specific presentations. I found the breakout rooms a little hectic at times, and sometimes wished that we spent more time hearing lecture directly, to understand more of the context. The presentations, though, I thought were a great way to engage individually with the class with preparation, and it was great to hear from everyone and mix things up.
N/Aa
Breakout rooms were most effective for discussion between students. Going through comprehension classes and vocabulary as a class was also very helpful.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Constantine is fantastic, but unless you are already completely and very comfortably fluent it's probably not the right place for you, even if you've done fourth year/other pre reqs.
Yes, recommend but beware that the readings are difficult and most often primary source.
Yes, definitely! It is very low-stress, however, you learn a lot. It is probably more fun to take while it's in-person so definitely take advantage of that!

I would definitely recommend this course to someone reasonably confident in their Russian and interested in delving into the events of 1917 in Russia. The use of primary sources as the main content of the class was awesome, as we were learning about the year from key participants in the events we learned about. I would caution that the readings are very difficult, and that a non-native speaker may feel somewhat lost or behind at certain points in the course. That said, its a fun challenge, and Constantine is nothing but supportive.
Yes! Interesting topic, great professor!
Yes. If you want to learn about Russian history while also improving your Russian language skills.

I would definitely recommend this course to another student. Although the course is difficult at times and there is a lot of work, it is extremely rewarding. You will learn a lot about the Russian Revolution from the professor and from the course material. The historical texts from the time of the revolution really give a deeper understanding of how and why the events unfolded as they did. You will get to read excerpts from accounts written by people who were leaders of the transitional government and leaders of their respective political parties. This course is a really interesting and in-depth look into that part of Russian history.
Yes if you're looking for an L5 Russian class and are at all interested in learning more about history, this is a great course to take
I would absolutely recommend this course to any student who is just at the point where they feel comfortable reading in Russian. This course will amplify those skills twice over.
No, not unless they're already completely fluent in Russian.
